questions.question: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the:
questions.answerA: Road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: Presence of a stop sign.
questions.answerC: Use of your turn signals.
questions.explanation: The amount of space you need to cross traffic depends on the road conditions, weather conditions, and oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other:
questions.answerA: It is always safe to proceed after one train passes.
questions.answerB: You must always stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: When one train passes, look for another train on the other track before proceeding.
questions.answerD: Honk your horn as you cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: If there are two railroad tracks next to each other, watch for a second approaching train after one train passes. Do not begin to cross the tracks until you’re sure no train is approaching from either direction on either track.

questions.question: At intersections with a "Yield" sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Yield the right-of-way to cross traffic that is near enough to cause conflict.
questions.answerB: Yield the right-of-way only to vehicles on your right.
questions.answerC: Always slow down and proceed without stopping.
questions.explanation: At a yield sign, you must slow down or stop, if necessary, and give the right-of-way to crossing or merging vehicles. Yield the right-of-way to any cross traffic that is close enough to cause conflict.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers:
questions.answerA: That the right lane ends and traffic should merge left.
questions.answerB: That the road curves ahead.
questions.answerC: About upcoming intersections.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the right lane on a multilane roadway ends ahead. Traffic in the right lane must merge left.

questions.question: Changing from one lane to another is best done:
questions.answerB: When a car is in your blind spot.
questions.answerC: Gradually and carefully.
questions.explanation: You should always change lanes gradually and carefully. Only change lanes when necessary. Every lane change increases the possibility of a traffic accident.

questions.question: You are preparing to exit the interstate. When should you start reducing your speed?
questions.answerA: About halfway through the deceleration lane.
questions.answerB: As you approach the deceleration lane.
questions.answerC: Immediately upon entering the deceleration lane.
questions.explanation: When leaving an interstate, you should maintain your speed until you enter the deceleration lane, at which point you should reduce your speed to the exit ramp's posted advisory speed.

questions.question: You may not park within ____ of an alley entrance, public driveway, or private driveway.
questions.answerB: 20 feet
questions.answerC: Five feet
questions.explanation: Vehicles, occupied or not, may not stand or park within five feet of an alley entrance, public driveway, or private driveway.

questions.question: If you need to stop quickly and your vehicle is not equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should:
questions.answerB: Firmly pump your brakes.
questions.answerC: Lightly tap the brakes.
questions.explanation: Pumping the brakes is generally the best way to stop a car in an emergency. The car will stop quickly and you will also be able to continue steering.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Two-way left turn.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This sign tells drivers the direction in which they must drive when turning onto a one-way street.

questions.question: When you are being tailgated:
questions.answerA: Move over to the right, if there is an open lane to your right.
questions.answerB: If there is not an open lane to your right, wait until the way is clear ahead and reduce your speed slowly to encourage the tailgater to drive around you.
questions.answerC: Never slow down abruptly.
questions.explanation: If you are being tailgated by another driver and there is a right lane, move over to the right. If there is no right lane, wait until the road ahead is clear and then reduce your speed slowly. This will encourage the tailgater to drive around you. Never slow down abruptly as this will only increase the risk of your vehicle being hit from behind.

questions.question: Before entering a roundabout, you must slow down and yield to:
questions.answerB: Bicyclists in the roundabout.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians in the roundabout.
questions.explanation: When entering a roundabout, you must yield to pedestrians, bicyclists, and vehicles that are already in the roundabout.

questions.question: This sign is used to warn drivers about:
questions.answerB: Road construction.
questions.answerC: An upcoming curve in the road.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead curves to the right.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a steady green arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should slow to a stop, if it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: May turn in the direction of the arrow after yielding to traffic and pedestrians already in the intersection.
questions.answerD: May drive straight through the intersection.
questions.explanation: A green arrow displayed on a traffic signal tells drivers that they may turn in the direction of the arrow. You must be in the proper lane for such a turn. Yield the right-of-way to vehicles and pedestrians already in the intersection.

questions.question: The best way to tell if you are permitted to pass another vehicle is to see if:
questions.answerA: There is a flashing green light ahead.
questions.answerB: The road ahead is straight.
questions.answerC: The vehicle ahead signals that it is okay to pass.
questions.answerD: There are solid or broken lane markings.
questions.explanation: The presence of solid or broken lane markings down the center of a road is the best indication of whether or not passing is permitted in an area. On a two-lane highway, you may not pass another vehicle if your lane is directly next to a solid line. You may not pass within 100 feet of an intersection.

questions.question: After passing a vehicle, it is safe to return to your driving lane when:
questions.answerA: The driver you passed signals for you to return to your lane.
questions.answerB: You signal your intention for three seconds.
questions.answerC: You see the headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.explanation: Before you return to your driving lane, be sure you are not dangerously close to the vehicle you have just passed. One way to do this is to look for the vehicle in your inside rearview mirror. When you can see both headlights in your rearview mirror, you may have enough room to return to your driving lane.

questions.question: In the District of Columbia, if you are traveling on a one-way street and you want to make a left turn onto another one-way street, it is illegal to make a left turn on a red traffic signal.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is illegal to make a left turn on a red traffic signal in the District of Columbia. You may make a right turn on a red traffic light where permitted.

questions.question: A slow-moving vehicle emblem is:
questions.answerB: A circular green sign.
questions.answerC: A diamond-shaped yellow sign.
questions.explanation: The slow-moving vehicle symbol is a reflective orange triangle. Expect vehicles using this emblem to be driving at speeds of 25 mph or slower.

questions.question: To help prevent crashes, you should:
questions.answerB: Ignore other drivers on the road.
questions.answerC: Drive only on side streets and back roads.
questions.explanation: Crashes often happen because one driver does something that other road users are not expecting. You should communicate with other motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians by doing things like signaling when slowing down, stopping, or changing direction. Use your emergency signals or horn when appropriate.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding seat belts and child restraints in vehicles?
questions.answerA: You should never place an infant or small child in the front seat of a vehicle with airbags.
questions.answerB: An airbag can be dangerous to an infant or small child, even in a low-speed collision.
questions.answerC: You should always make sure all your passengers are using a seat belt or child restraint.
questions.explanation: Before you drive, always fasten your seat belt and make sure all your passengers are using seat belts or child restraints. Studies have shown that if you use seat belts, your chances of being hurt or killed in a traffic crash are greatly reduced. Children age 12 and under should always ride properly restrained in a rear seat. Never put a rear-facing infant restraint in the front seat of a vehicle with a front passenger airbag.

questions.question: If you park facing uphill on a street with a curb, set the parking brake and:
questions.answerA: Turn the front wheels toward the curb.
questions.answerB: Turn the front wheels away from the curb.
questions.answerC: Leave the front wheels straight.
questions.explanation: When parking uphill on a road that has a curb, your wheels should be turned away from the curb. When parking uphill on a street without a curb or when parking downhill, your wheels should be turned toward the curb or edge of the road.

questions.question: Signs indicating areas of public recreation are:
questions.answerB: Red.
questions.answerC: Green.
questions.explanation: Signs that are brown indicate areas of cultural and historical significance or of public recreation. They can be a helpful resource when traveling in unfamiliar locations.

questions.question: This bicyclist is signaling:
questions.answerB: An upcoming stop.
questions.answerC: A right turn.
questions.explanation: Bicycles do not have turn signals so bicyclists use hand and arm signals to alert other drivers to their intentions. If a bicyclist puts their left arm straight out, they are signaling that they intend to turn left.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ahead.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of two-way traffic ahead.

questions.question: If you find yourself in a skid:
questions.answerB: Stay off the brakes.
questions.answerC: Brake abruptly.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle begins to skid, do not use the brakes. Braking could make the skid worse.

questions.question: Motorists are not required to yield to pedestrians if they are walking against the traffic light.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: You must always yield the right-of-way to pedestrians. Be aware of the possibility that pedestrians may misjudge traffic signals and cross against a light.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Winding road ahead.
questions.answerC: Reserved parking for persons with disabilities.
questions.explanation: This sign warns that two lanes of traffic going the same direction will soon merge into one lane.

questions.question: This white sign means:
questions.answerA: The railroad crossing is controlled. Continue at your regular speed.
questions.answerB: Look, listen, and prepare to stop at the crossing if necessary.
questions.answerC: Stop at the railroad tracks and wait for a signal before crossing.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, you must look, listen, slow down, and prepare to stop. Let any trains pass before you proceed.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: Sharp turn to the right ahead.
questions.answerB: Upcoming sharp left and right turns.
questions.answerC: Winding road ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns the driver that there is an upcoming winding road. Speed should be adjusted appropriately.

questions.question: Which is the most common cause of traffic crashes?
questions.answerB: Human error
questions.answerC: Bad weather
questions.explanation: Crashes often occur when one driver does not see another vehicle or when a driver does something unexpected. Communicate with other drivers on the road to help prevent traffic crashes.

questions.question: To prevent hydroplaning, you should:
questions.answerA: Ensure that your tires have good tread depth.
questions.answerB: Ensure that your tires are properly inflated.
questions.answerC: Reduce your speed when driving in the rain.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, you should ensure that the tires on your vehicle have good tread depth and are inflated to the proper pressure. Reduce the speed of your vehicle when driving in the rain. Hydroplaning occurs most frequently at higher speeds.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Divided highway ends.
questions.answerC: Two-way traffic.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign indicates that the divided highway is about to end.

questions.question: Your vehicle strikes an unattended parked vehicle and you cannot locate the vehicle’s owner. You:
questions.answerA: Have done as much as you can.
questions.answerB: Must stay until the police arrive.
questions.answerC: Must leave a written notice containing your name, your address, and the circumstances of the accident.
questions.explanation: Upon striking an unattended vehicle, stop and try to locate the owner. If you cannot find the owner, leave a written notice containing your name, your address, and the circumstances of the accident.

questions.question: A traffic light displaying a green arrow and a red light means that:
questions.answerA: You may only drive straight ahead.
questions.answerB: You may drive only in the direction of the green arrow.
questions.answerC: You must wait for a solid green light to proceed in any direction.
questions.answerD: Vehicles moving in any direction must stop.
questions.explanation: If a green arrow is shown with a red light, you can only drive in the direction of the arrow and only if the intersection is clear.

questions.question: When driving under snowy or icy conditions:
questions.answerA: It is safe to use your cruise control.
questions.answerB: Make speed and directional changes more gradually than you would otherwise.
questions.answerC: Drive as you would under normal conditions.
questions.explanation: When driving under snowy or icy conditions, you should make speed and directional changes gradually. Never use cruise control when driving on snow or ice because your tires may lose contact with the road and you will lose control of your vehicle.

questions.question: You are driving on a city street and see an emergency vehicle with flashing lights behind you. What should you do?
questions.answerA: Drive to the right edge of the road and slow down.
questions.answerB: Drive to the right edge of the road and stop.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane, slow down, and let it pass.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and lights. Drive to the right edge of the road and stop until the emergency vehicle has passed. If you are within an intersection, drive through the intersection first and then stop.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: End of construction zone.
questions.answerC: School crossing ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a flagger ahead controlling traffic in a construction area.

questions.question: Which of these statements is true about drugs and driving?
questions.answerA: Any prescription drug is safe to use if you don't feel drowsy.
questions.answerB: Even over-the-counter drugs can impair your driving.
questions.answerC: Only illegal drugs can impair your driving.
questions.explanation: Legal prescription and over-the-counter drugs can impair your ability to drive, including drugs taken for colds, hay fever, allergies, or to calm nerves or muscles. It is illegal to drive while under the influence of any drug that impairs your ability to drive safely; this law does not differentiate between illegal, prescription, or over-the-counter drugs.

questions.question: When driving on gravel or dirt roads:
questions.answerA: Your tires grip the road better than when you are driving on pavement.
questions.answerB: Your tires do not have as much traction as they do on pavement, so you must slow down.
questions.answerC: Visibility is better than on pavement.
questions.explanation: Your tires do not have as much traction on loose gravel and dirt roads as they do on concrete and asphalt roads. When driving on gravel or dirt, you must slow down. It will take you much longer to stop and it is much easier to skid when turning.

questions.question: Coming to a complete stop at an intersection, yielding to cross traffic/pedestrians, and then proceeding through the intersection when the way is clear corresponds with:
questions.answerB: A flashing yellow light.
questions.answerC: A solid green light.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to cross traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: The road ahead winds with a series of turns or curves.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs provide notice to road users of a situation that might not be readily apparent and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers to be careful when driving under wet conditions as the pavement will become slippery and more difficult to navigate safely.

questions.question: The most common mistake that drivers make when backing is failing to look both ways behind them.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: The most common mistake that drivers make when backing up is failing to look both ways behind them. Mirrors do not give you a full view. To see as much as possible, turn your body and head to the right and look through the rear window.

questions.question: This sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing that does not have a signal. You should:
questions.answerB: Proceed at a consistent speed while looking and listening for approaching trains.
questions.answerC: Slow down, look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby.
questions.explanation: At a railroad crossing marked with this sign, a driver should look both ways, listen for any trains, and be prepared to stop if any trains are nearby. Never try to outdrive an oncoming train.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: You must turn left ahead.
questions.answerC: Do not enter.
questions.explanation: This signs warns that a four-way intersection is ahead.

questions.question: You are waiting to turn left at a multilane intersection and opposing traffic is blocking your view. You should:
questions.answerA: Accelerate rapidly when the first lane you need to cross is clear.
questions.answerB: Wait until you can see all the lanes you need to cross before going ahead with your turn.
questions.answerC: Wait for an oncoming driver to wave you across the intersection.
questions.answerD: Edge your car into each lane of opposing traffic as soon as it clears.
questions.explanation: You should never start a left turn until you can see that all the lanes you need to cross are clear and that you can safely make the turn.

questions.question: Which of the following must you obey over the other three?
questions.answerB: A police officer
questions.answerC: A stop sign
questions.explanation: Directions given by traffic officers take precedence over signs, signals, and pavement markings. People authorized to direct traffic include police officers, fire police, highway work area flag persons, and school crossing persons.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Buggy warning.
questions.answerC: Limited parking.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that there is an upcoming stop sign and that they should prepare to come to a complete stop before proceeding.

questions.question: If an officer is directing traffic at a working traffic light, drivers should:
questions.answerA: Follow the directions indicated by the traffic light.
questions.answerB: Follow the directions given by the officer.
questions.answerC: Honk at the officer.
questions.answerD: Check to see what the cars next to them are doing.
questions.explanation: Traffic signals are placed at intersections to keep traffic moving and to help prevent crashes. Drivers, pedestrians, and cyclists must obey these signals, except in instances when an officer is directing traffic.

questions.question: You may cross double solid yellow lines:
questions.answerB: To turn into a driveway.
questions.answerC: To pass another car.
questions.explanation: Double solid lines indicate that you may not pass or change lanes. You cannot cross the lines unless it is to turn left to enter or exit a highway, to turn into or from a driveway, or to make a U-turn (where permitted).

questions.question: Having a driver license is a:
questions.answerB: Privilege, not a right.
questions.answerC: Requirement.
questions.explanation: Holding a driver license is not a right. It is a privilege that must be earned and maintained.

questions.question: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait until it is safe to do so, then gradually re-enter the roadway.
questions.answerB: Turn back onto the roadway immediately.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.explanation: If your wheels drop off the roadway or pavement edge, do not attempt to turn back onto the roadway immediately. Instead, reduce your speed, check traffic, and gradually turn back onto the roadway when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A red arrow pointing to the right on a traffic light means you may:
questions.answerA: Turn in that direction after slowing and checking for traffic.
questions.answerB: Not turn in that direction until the light turns green.
questions.answerC: Turn in that direction after you come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: A red arrow means "stop." You must remain stopped until a green light or green arrow appears. Do not turn against a red arrow.

questions.question: To enter a freeway:
questions.answerA: Signal, yield to existing traffic, and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving.
questions.answerB: Signal and enter the freeway. Freeway traffic must yield.
questions.answerC: Drive slowly so you can check traffic.
questions.answerD: Always come to a complete stop first.
questions.explanation: When merging into traffic, you should signal and enter at the same speed that traffic is moving. Always yield to other traffic when entering a roadway.

questions.question: While driving on a roadway with a single broken white centerline:
questions.answerA: You must stay within your lane.
questions.answerB: You may cross the centerline to change lanes.
questions.answerC: You may change lanes only from the left lane.
questions.explanation: White lines between lanes indicate that the lanes are traveling in the same direction. Broken white line markings indicate that it is legal to pass another vehicle when safe.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Railroad warning.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that a divided highway begins ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: Pedestrians walking along the road ahead.
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing ahead.
questions.answerC: Pedestrians must not cross here.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign alerts drivers to where pedestrians may be crossing. If a pedestrian is crossing in a crosswalk marked with this sign, drivers must stop and remain stopped until the pedestrian is no longer in the crosswalk.

questions.question: You must yield the right-of-way to an emergency vehicle that is using its siren and flashing lights by:
questions.answerA: Driving as closely to the right edge of the road as possible and stopping.
questions.answerB: Moving into the right lane and driving slowly until it has passed.
questions.answerC: Stopping immediately, even if you are within an intersection.
questions.explanation: You must yield the right-of-way to any emergency vehicle that is using its siren and flashing lights. Do this by driving to the right edge of the road and stopping, taking care not to stop in an intersection. You may move again after the emergency vehicle has passed.

questions.question: You should signal continuously while turning because it:
questions.answerA: Is illegal to turn off your signal before completing a turn.
questions.answerB: Lets other drivers know what your intentions are.
questions.answerC: Is always unsafe to turn off a signal before completing a turn.
questions.explanation: You should always signal when turning, changing lanes, slowing down, or stopping so that other drivers, motorcyclists, bicyclists, and pedestrians will know your intentions.

questions.question: When passing, you should move back into the right lane when:
questions.answerA: You are one vehicle length ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerB: You can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: You are 50 feet ahead of the passed vehicle.
questions.explanation: Do not pass unless you have enough space to return to the driving lane. Before you return to the driving lane, be sure you have enough room between yourself and the vehicle you have passed. When you can see both headlights of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror, it is safe to return to the driving lane.

questions.question: Always signal when:
questions.answerB: Pulling into or out of a parking space.
questions.answerC: Pulling into traffic from a parking area or alley.
questions.explanation: Your turn signals should always be used when you make any movement to the left or right. You should use your signal when pulling into traffic from a curbside parking space, moving into a new lane, or passing another vehicle.

questions.question: When a stop is required at an intersection and no markings appear to indicate a stop line or crosswalk, a driver:
questions.answerB: Is required to slow down to make sure crossing traffic is clear.
questions.answerC: Should stop only at a place where they can see at least 200 feet on either side, even if they have to enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.answerD: Should stop where they have a clear view of approaching traffic before they enter the intersecting roadway.
questions.explanation: If there is no stop line or crosswalk, you should stop at the point nearest to the intersecting roadway where you can get a view of approaching traffic. You should not enter the intersecting roadway to gain a better view.

questions.question: You notice a vehicle defect which may affect the safe operation of your vehicle. You should:
questions.answerA: Correct the defect as soon as possible.
questions.answerB: Correct the defect when you can afford it.
questions.answerC: Drive the vehicle at slower speeds.
questions.explanation: Any defect that may affect the safe operation of a vehicle should be corrected as soon as possible. Defects should be corrected before the vehicle is driven.

questions.question: When approaching a traffic signal displaying a flashing yellow arrow, drivers:
questions.answerA: Should merge into a lane in the direction of the arrow.
questions.answerB: Should come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: May turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Have the right-of-way and may expect oncoming traffic to stop for them.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow arrow indicates that left turns are allowed in the direction of the arrow. However, the oncoming traffic has a green light and you must yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.

questions.question: This sign is a warning that you are approaching:
questions.answerB: A crosswalk.
questions.answerC: A railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: Which of the following commonly causes traffic accidents?
questions.answerB: Excessive speed under the driving conditions
questions.answerC: Following other vehicles too closely
questions.explanation: Driving too fast for conditions is a major cause of motor vehicle crashes. Being inattentive to surroundings can cause a driver to collide with other vehicles. Most rear-end collisions are caused by drivers following other vehicles too closely.

questions.question: To see vehicles in your blind spots, you should check:
questions.answerB: The outside rearview mirror.
questions.answerC: Over your shoulders.
questions.explanation: By definition, blind spots are areas that cannot be seen using your mirrors. To check your blind spots, you should look over your shoulders.

questions.question: A school bus is stopped ahead of you in your lane with its red lights flashing. You should:
questions.answerA: Stop and proceed when you think all of the children have exited the bus.
questions.answerB: Slow to 25 mph and pass cautiously.
questions.answerC: Stop for as long as the red lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: When a stopped school bus is using its flashing red lights, approaching drivers must stop and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing. If the school bus is on the opposite side of a divided highway, drivers do not need to stop.

questions.question: It is dangerous to follow a motorcycle too closely because:
questions.answerA: They do not follow the same rules as motor vehicles.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle can stop much faster than a standard vehicle.
questions.answerC: They brake more slowly than motor vehicles.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can stop quickly and following them too closely endangers your life and that of the motorcyclist. If the motorcyclist makes a mistake, you need to have enough time and space to avoid a crash.

questions.question: The sign with this shape and color is a ____ sign.
questions.answerB: Wrong way
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped warning signs like this are only used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: To avoid being blinded by the glare of oncoming headlights:
questions.answerA: Focus your eyes on the centerline of the road.
questions.answerB: Glance to the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Focus your eyes straight ahead.
questions.explanation: Glancing back and forth between the right side of the road and the road directly ahead allows you to avoid the glare of oncoming headlights while still staying safely in your lane.

questions.question: Increasing your vehicle’s speed:
questions.answerB: Decreases your field of vision.
questions.answerC: Makes it easier to see cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Has no effect on your field of vision.
questions.explanation: The faster you drive, the smaller your field of vision becomes. As your speed increases and your field of vision decreases, you must be extra alert to potential hazards.

questions.question: Drinking coffee after drinking alcohol:
questions.answerB: Cancels the effect of the alcohol.
questions.answerC: Has no effect on blood alcohol concentration.
questions.explanation: Drinking coffee will not reduce your blood alcohol concentration (BAC). While it may help you to stay awake, it cannot change your BAC or make you sober.

questions.question: When you see this road sign, you should:
questions.answerB: Keep left.
questions.answerC: Pass with caution.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. This sign indicates that a divided highway is beginning and cars should keep to the right.

questions.question: Signs with orange backgrounds are:
questions.answerB: Construction and maintenance warning signs.
questions.answerC: Regulatory signs.
questions.explanation: The color orange is used only for construction and maintenance warning signs.

questions.question: If pedestrians are illegally crossing in the middle of the street instead of in a crosswalk, you:
questions.answerB: Do not have to stop for them.
questions.answerC: Should honk your horn at them.
questions.explanation: You must yield to pedestrians at all times. If the pedestrians are jaywalking or crossing the street where they should not be, you must still stop for them.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No turning.
questions.answerC: No left turn.
questions.explanation: This sign prohibits U-turns. Do not make a U-turn where this sign is posted.

questions.question: A driver approaching a flashing red traffic signal must:
questions.answerB: Drive carefully without stopping.
questions.answerC: Merge to the right.
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means that you must stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and go only when it is safe. At a railroad crossing, a flashing red light indicates that a train is approaching. Yield to the train, and go only when the lights have stopped flashing and all other active warning devices deactivate.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerA: You must drive slowly and sound your horn.
questions.answerB: A bus stop is ahead.
questions.answerC: You are entering a school's parking lot.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazardous conditions and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign tells drivers that they are approaching a school zone and that they should slow down and watch for children.

questions.question: To avoid traction loss on wet roads, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes firmly.
questions.answerC: Slow down.
questions.explanation: To prevent hydroplaning, lower your speed in response to wet roads and keep your tires in good condition. If you detect a loss of control, take your foot off the gas, do not apply the brakes, maintain the direction of the vehicle, and allow the vehicle to slow to a manageable speed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Do not enter.
questions.answerC: Railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: This sign means that it is not safe for drivers to enter the indicated road or driveway from their current direction. If you come across one of these signs, you should immediately turn around and drive a different way.

questions.question: How fast you drive does not affect the distance your vehicle travels after you brake to come to a stop.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: When driving in high-speed traffic, it is extremely important to stay well behind the vehicle in front of you. As your speed increases, the distance it will take for your vehicle to stop also increases.

questions.question: At a school crossing sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stop, whether there is a stop sign or not.
questions.answerB: Watch for children and be ready to stop.
questions.answerC: Always sound your horn when you see children.
questions.explanation: Pentagonal signs mean you are approaching a school zone and/or school crossing. When you see these signs, be alert and prepare to stop.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should stop and:
questions.answerA: Check for vehicles only in the direction that you plan on going, then proceed.
questions.answerB: Let all vehicles that arrive before or after you go first.
questions.answerC: Check for traffic in all directions before proceeding.
questions.explanation: At a stop sign, you must come to a full stop and check for traffic in all directions before proceeding.

questions.question: At an intersection with stop signs on all corners, yield the right-of-way to any driver:
questions.answerB: Who arrived before you.
questions.answerC: Across from your vehicle.
questions.explanation: After coming to a full stop, vehicles should proceed through a four-way stop in the order in which they arrive to the intersection. If multiple vehicles arrive at the same time, the vehicle on the left must yield the right-of-way to the vehicle on the right.

questions.question: Hydroplaning is usually caused by:
questions.answerB: Sudden stops.
questions.answerC: Sudden turns.
questions.explanation: Your tires become less effective at clearing water from the road as you increase your speed. If you drive too fast, they may lose their grip entirely, leaving the vehicle sliding on a film of water. This is known as "hydroplaning."

questions.question: Roads become very slippery:
questions.answerA: When it has been raining for an hour or more.
questions.answerB: The day after it rains.
questions.answerC: For the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm.
questions.answerD: Right after the rain has stopped.
questions.explanation: Pavement can become very slippery within the first 10 to 15 minutes of a rainstorm because the rain causes oil in the asphalt to rise to the surface of the road. This problem becomes even worse in hot weather. The heat combined with the water causes more oil to rise to the road surface.

questions.question: If you are driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull off the right side of the road and let traffic pass.
questions.answerC: Not let the other cars pass your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Driving more slowly than the flow of traffic can be hazardous. If you are on a two-lane, two-way road and driving so slowly that traffic is backing up behind you, you are required to pull off the road and let the other vehicles pass. Only drive significantly under the speed limit when conditions require it.

questions.question: When turning or changing lanes, you must:
questions.answerA: Always signal your intentions, even when no visible traffic is present.
questions.answerB: Signal only if there is visible traffic.
questions.answerC: Signal only when driving at night.
questions.answerD: Signal only when driving in heavy traffic at night.
questions.explanation: Always signal your intentions when changing lanes, turning, or pulling away from a curb. Do not allow yourself to become lazy and form the bad habit of not following this law.

questions.question: What should you do if your accelerator sticks while you are driving?
questions.answerA: Reach down and attempt to pull it up.
questions.answerB: Shift to park.
questions.answerC: Shift to neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake.
questions.explanation: If your accelerator sticks while you are driving, keep your eyes on the road. Quickly shift the vehicle into neutral and apply steady pressure on the brake pedal. Pull off the road when it is safe to do so and turn off the engine.

questions.question: What should a driver do when approaching a traffic control signal that is not in operation?
questions.answerA: Come to a full stop and yield the right-of-way before entering the intersection.
questions.answerB: If the intersection is clear, the driver does not need to stop.
questions.answerC: Drive quickly through the intersection to get out of the way of other vehicles.
questions.explanation: When traffic control signals are not working, a driver must always treat the intersection as an all-way stop and come to a complete stop, unless otherwise directed by law enforcement. The driver must then look and yield the right-of-way before entering the intersection.

questions.question: Worn or bald tires:
questions.answerB: Are likely to hydroplane.
questions.answerC: Can increase your stopping distance.
questions.explanation: Worn or bald tires can increase your stopping distance and make turning more difficult. Tires without adequate tread also increase the risk of hydroplaning.

questions.question: You come to an intersection that is blocked by other traffic. You should:
questions.answerA: Go slowly until the traffic ahead moves.
questions.answerB: Get as close as possible to the car in front of you.
questions.answerC: Stay out of the intersection until you can pass through.
questions.answerD: Sound your horn to make the cars move up.
questions.explanation: You cannot enter an intersection if traffic is backed up on the other side and you cannot get completely through the intersection. Wait until traffic ahead clears so you do not block the intersection.

questions.question: When approaching a person who is crossing the street while using a white cane or guide dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop until the person is well away from your path of travel.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn as you proceed past them.
questions.answerC: Carefully drive around them.
questions.explanation: When approaching a pedestrian who is using a white cane or guide dog while crossing the street, you must stop until the person is well away from your path of travel. Always yield the right-of-way to blind pedestrians.

questions.question: Traffic signals sometimes display arrows to control turns from specific lanes. A solid red arrow:
questions.answerA: Is never used as a traffic signal.
questions.answerB: Has the same meaning as a circular red traffic light.
questions.answerC: Means that drivers may turn in the direction indicated by the arrow.
questions.answerD: Means that the traffic the arrow is pointing toward must stop.
questions.explanation: A solid red arrow in a traffic signal means the same thing as a circular red traffic light. When an arrow is red, traffic in the indicated lane must stop and may not turn in the direction that the arrow is pointing.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection with a steady yellow traffic light. If you have not already entered the intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Reduce you speed and proceed carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a safe stop.
questions.explanation: When a steady yellow light appears on a traffic signal, you should prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection, you should clear the intersection as quickly as possible.

questions.question: To avoid being in a truck or bus driver’s blind spot, you should:
questions.answerB: Avoid driving alongside them and avoid tailgating.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights at them.
questions.explanation: Because a large vehicle, such as a truck or bus, has large blind spots to its sides and rear, avoid driving alongside such a vehicle and do not tailgate one.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: The road ahead turns sharply right, then left.
questions.answerB: The road ahead turns sharply left, then right.
questions.answerC: The road ahead curves to the left.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that the road ahead will turn sharply to the right and then to the left.

questions.question: A driver entering public traffic from a driveway or private road:
questions.answerB: Should yield to drivers already on the public road.
questions.answerC: May force their way into traffic.
questions.answerD: Can assume that other drivers will change lanes to make room.
questions.explanation: If you are entering traffic from a driveway or private road, you should yield to drivers already on the public road. Merge safely into traffic when you are able to do so.

questions.question: You are approaching an intersection at the posted speed limit when the signal turns yellow. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and proceed through the intersection without caution.
questions.answerB: Speed up to cross the intersection before the light turns red.
questions.answerC: Stop before entering the intersection, if you can do so safely.
questions.explanation: A solid yellow light means "caution" and signals that the light will soon turn red. You should stop at a solid yellow light if you can do so safely; otherwise, you should cautiously cross the intersection.

questions.question: Because driving involves some risk, it is wise to continually improve your driving and observation skills.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: Driving can become unsafe if drivers believe they have nothing to improve. For your safety and the safety of others, always strive to improve your driving and observation skills.

questions.question: What message will be found on this yellow pennant-shaped sign?
questions.answerB: Right turns permitted.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped yellow signs like this are used to indicate a no passing zone.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Road construction area.
questions.answerC: Upcoming narrowing of roadway.
questions.explanation: This sign warns of a dangerous downgrade or hill ahead. The hill may be very long or steep, or it may have sharp curves.

questions.question: Which is not a factor in determining the distance that it takes to stop your vehicle?
questions.answerB: Braking distance
questions.answerC: Reaction distance
questions.explanation: The distance required to stop your vehicle depends on perception time, reaction distance, and braking distance. This changes with speed and road conditions.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No left turn.
questions.answerC: No right turn.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that right turns are prohibited. Do not make a right turn at an intersection where this sign is posted.

questions.question: As you near an intersection, the traffic light changes from green to yellow. Your best action is to:
questions.answerA: Speed up to beat the red light.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes sharply to stop.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to stop in the center of the intersection.
questions.answerD: Be prepared to stop before the intersection.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow traffic light indicates that the light will soon change to red. You should be prepared to stop for the red light, if it is safe to do so.

questions.question: If your car's suspension is bad, it can cause:
questions.answerB: Squealing brakes.
questions.answerC: Slack in the steering.
questions.explanation: Your suspension helps you control your vehicle and provides a comfortable ride over varying road surfaces. If your vehicle bounces a lot after driving over a bump, or is generally hard to control, you may need new suspension parts.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you should:
questions.answerA: Watch for traffic merging from the right.
questions.answerB: Merge right.
questions.answerC: Turn left.
questions.explanation: Warning signs alert drivers to upcoming hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers about potential traffic merging into their lane from the right.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should use your low beam headlights:
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: You should always use your low beam headlights when driving in fog. High beam headlights may cause the light to reflect off of the fog and into your eyes.

questions.question: What should you do when you see this sign?
questions.answerA: Look for a train station ahead.
questions.answerB: Signal before going any further.
questions.answerC: Slow down and yield to trains.
questions.explanation: A round sign means you are approaching a railroad crossing. This sign is posted a few hundred feet in front of the tracks and tells drivers to slow down, look, listen, and prepare to stop.

questions.question: Continuous hard braking on ice and snow often:
questions.answerB: Locks the front wheels of a vehicle, causing a loss of steering.
questions.answerC: Keeps the brakes from freezing.
questions.explanation: Continuous hard braking on snow and ice can result in the locking of the front brake, causing a loss of steering. To avoid the need for excessive braking, make sure to maintain an appropriate speed for conditions.

questions.question: An approaching driver fails to dim their high beam headlights. Where should you look?
questions.answerA: At the wheels of the approaching vehicle.
questions.answerB: Toward the right side of the road.
questions.answerC: Toward the left side of the road.
questions.answerD: Straight down the middle of the road.
questions.explanation: If an approaching driver fails to dim their high beams, glance toward the right side of the road. This will keep you from being blinded by the other vehicle’s headlights and will allow you to see enough of the road to stay on course until the other vehicle has passed.

questions.question: At night, it is hardest to see:
questions.answerB: Pedestrians.
questions.answerC: Other motorists.
questions.explanation: Compared to signs and other roadside objects, pedestrians are hardest to see at night.

questions.question: The risk of hydroplaning can can be reduced by driving:
questions.answerB: More quickly.
questions.answerC: More slowly.
questions.explanation: Because hydroplaning is caused by driving too quickly in wet conditions, the risk of it happening can be reduced by driving more slowly.

questions.question: You should use your horn when:
questions.answerA: Another vehicle is in your way.
questions.answerB: It may help prevent a collision.
questions.answerC: Another driver makes a mistake.
questions.explanation: Only use your horn when it is necessary to avoid collisions. Do not use your horn if a driver or bicyclist is moving slowly and you want him or her to drive faster or get out of your way.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: One-way.
questions.answerC: Cattle crossing.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers turning left at a green light must yield to oncoming traffic and may complete the turn when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: Many crashes are caused by:
questions.answerA: Drivers traveling too fast for conditions.
questions.answerB: Drivers consistently checking their mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerC: Drivers yielding the right-of-way.
questions.answerD: Drivers maintaining a four-second following distance.
questions.explanation: Many crashes are caused by drivers who are driving too fast for conditions. Always drive within the legal speed limits and decrease your speed any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If you come to an intersection and your view to the side is blocked, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and look both ways.
questions.answerB: Maintain your speed and look both ways.
questions.answerC: Stop, then inch forward until you can see clearly in both directions.
questions.explanation: Drivers must slow down when approaching an intersection. If a clear view of cross traffic is obscured, a driver should come to a stop and inch forward until they can see clearly in both directions.

questions.question: This sign shows one type of:
questions.answerB: Road curve.
questions.answerC: Right turn.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually yellow with black markings. They alert you to conditions that are immediately ahead. This sign warns drivers that another road crosses the highway ahead.

questions.question: You are coming to an intersection with a flashing red light. You should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and yield the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: Slow down and drive carefully through the intersection.
questions.answerC: Come to a complete stop, check the traffic, and go when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: A flashing red traffic light means the same thing as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to other traffic and pedestrians, and then proceed when it safe to do so.

questions.question: A U-turn is not permitted:
questions.answerB: On or near any curve or hill.
questions.answerC: On a straight roadway with a clear view for 500 feet in both directions.
questions.explanation: You must never turn around while on or near any curve or hill. You may not be able to see oncoming traffic or pedestrians and may cause a collision.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Cross the centerline in an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spots by looking over your left or right shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: Before changing lanes, check for drivers trying to pass you who may be trying to enter the same lane as you. Look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. You should never attempt to pass or otherwise change lanes in an intersection.

questions.question: Vehicle stopping distances never depend on:
questions.answerB: The time of day.
questions.answerC: The condition of your vehicle's brakes.
questions.answerD: The condition and type of your vehicle's tires.
questions.explanation: The distance that a vehicle needs to stop depends on the motorist's reaction time, weather and visibility conditions, the vehicle's weight, the conditions of the vehicle's brakes, the condition and type of the vehicle's tires, roadway conditions, and speed.

questions.question: If a traffic signal light is green and a police officer signals for you to stop, you should:
questions.answerB: Obey the traffic signal.
questions.answerC: Do what the vehicle in front of you does.
questions.explanation: Drivers must obey any instructions given by a police officer, even if the instructions contradict laws, signs, signals, or markings that would otherwise apply.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Merge.
questions.answerC: Upcoming change in direction.
questions.explanation: An eight-sided red sign means "stop."

questions.question: While obtaining your driver license, you may:
questions.answerB: Choose to become an organ and tissue donor.
questions.answerC: Register to vote.
questions.explanation: If you are 18 years of age or older, you may choose to become an organ and tissue donor when obtaining your driver license. If you are a male between the ages 18 and 25, the DC DMV will register you with Selective Service unless you use a waiver form to opt out. If you are a citizen of the United States who will be at least 18 years of age by the time of the next election, you may register to vote or update your registration.

questions.question: It is more dangerous to drive at night than during the day because:
questions.answerA: You cannot see as far ahead at night.
questions.answerB: The road is always more slippery at night.
questions.answerC: Your reaction time is slower at night.
questions.explanation: With decreased visibility and the glare of oncoming headlights, you cannot see as far ahead at night as you can during the day. Always use headlights and exercise caution when driving in the dark.

questions.question: In a vehicle equipped with airbags, the safest place for children age 12 and under to ride is in:
questions.answerB: The back seat.
questions.answerC: The bed of a pick-up truck.
questions.explanation: While airbags provide supplemental protection for adults in the event of a crash, they pose a severe safety risk for children. Anyone age 12 or under should sit in the back seat of a vehicle with airbags.

questions.question: Hydroplaning occurs when tires ride on a thin film of water instead of on the surface of the road. To prevent hydroplaning in rainy weather, you should:
questions.answerA: Put on your cruise control to maintain a constant speed.
questions.answerB: Decrease your speed.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder of the road as soon as it starts to rain.
questions.explanation: In rainy weather, you should lower your speed to reduce the risk of hydroplaning. Driving too fast may cause your tires to ride up on the water and lose contact with the surface of the road, making it very difficult to control your vehicle.

questions.question: Allow a larger space cushion than usual when stopping:
questions.answerB: At an intersection.
questions.answerC: At a stop sign.
questions.explanation: You should allow more space in front of your vehicle than usual when you are stopped on an uphill slope. If the vehicle in front of you rolls backward toward your vehicle when traffic begins to move again, it is less likely that there will be a collision.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerA: You must travel through the intersection at the posted speed limit.
questions.answerB: The maximum speed limit under ideal conditions is 55 mph.
questions.answerC: You must not travel below the speed indicated.
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs provide notice to road users of traffic laws that must be obeyed. This particular sign tells you the maximum speed limit for the stretch of highway where it is posted. You may drive more slowly than the posted speed limit, based on road conditions, but it is illegal to drive any faster than the posted speed limit.

questions.question: When a school bus is stopped on the road ahead to load or unload children, you must:
questions.answerA: Come to a complete stop until all the children have left the bus.
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop until the red lights stop flashing and the stop arm is withdrawn.
questions.answerC: Change lanes, drive slowly, and pass the bus cautiously.
questions.explanation: When a school bus is stopped on the road ahead with its lights flashing and its stop arm extended, you must come to a complete stop and wait to proceed until the lights have stopped flashing and the stop arm is withdrawn. Even after the bus begins to move again, do not proceed until you are sure there are no children crossing the road ahead of you.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Bicycles not allowed.
questions.answerC: Bicycle repair shop ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign provides advance warning that bicycles may be present.

questions.question: A single broken yellow line down the center of a two-lane road indicates:
questions.answerA: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerB: Lanes are moving in opposite directions and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.answerC: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are not permitted to pass.
questions.answerD: Lanes are moving in the same direction and drivers are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.
questions.explanation: Yellow lines are used to separate traffic moving in opposite directions. Dashed lines indicate that drivers directly next to the line are permitted to pass when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: A steady yellow light at an intersection means:
questions.answerB: Yield to other cars.
questions.answerC: Slow down and prepare to stop.
questions.explanation: A steady yellow light indicates that a steady red light will soon appear. If you are driving toward an intersection and a yellow light appears, slow down and prepare to stop. If you are already within the intersection or cannot stop safely before entering the intersection, continue through carefully.

questions.question: When approaching a flashing yellow light, drivers should:
questions.answerB: Come to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Turn on their headlights.
questions.answerD: Slow down and proceed with caution.
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light warns of a hazard. Slow down and proceed with caution.

questions.question: Two solid white lines painted across a traffic lane show the boundaries of a crosswalk. As a driver, you should know that:
questions.answerA: Motor vehicles have the right-of-way over pedestrians in crosswalks.
questions.answerB: When pedestrians are in crosswalks, they should be given the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: No one has the right-of-way in a crosswalk.
questions.answerD: Pedestrians are responsible to stay out of the way of all traffic.
questions.explanation: Crosswalk lines show pedestrians where to safely cross a road or street. Crosswalks may be marked by horizontal lines, vertical lines, or a combination of the two. You must always stop for pedestrians who are in a crosswalk.

questions.question: It is legal to go faster than the speed limit when passing another vehicle.
questions.answerB: False
questions.explanation: It is always unlawful to exceed the posted speed limit, even when passing another vehicle.

questions.question: This road sign means:
questions.answerB: Lane reduction; the right lane ends soon.
questions.answerC: Highway entrance ramp ahead.
questions.answerD: Lane reduction; the left lane ends soon.
questions.explanation: This sign indicate that the right lane ends ahead.

questions.question: A “No standing” sign at a certain location means:
questions.answerA: You may never stop your vehicle there.
questions.answerB: You may park there if the driver remains in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: You may stop temporarily only to pickup or discharge passengers.
questions.answerD: You may stop to load or unload merchandise.
questions.explanation: A "No standing" sign means that you may only make a temporary stop to load or discharge passengers.

questions.question: "No passing zone" signs tell drivers:
questions.answerB: That it is not safe to pass.
questions.answerC: To maintain a steady speed.
questions.explanation: If you come across a "No passing zone" sign, it is not legal to pass in the indicated area. You are likely driving in an area with restricted visibility where it would be unsafe to pass another vehicle.

questions.question: A bicyclist who doesn’t obey traffic laws:
questions.answerA: Is in the right because bicyclists don’t have to obey traffic laws.
questions.answerB: Can be ticketed.
questions.answerC: Will always receive a warning from law enforcement.
questions.explanation: All bicyclists have the same rights, duties, and responsibilities as drivers of motor vehicles. Motorists and bicyclists who do not obey traffic laws can be ticketed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No parking.
questions.answerC: Right lane closed.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow with black markings. This sign warns drivers that they are approaching a winding road and that they should adjust their speed accordingly.

questions.question: While obtaining your driver license, you may:
questions.answerB: Choose to become an organ and tissue donor.
questions.answerC: Register to vote.
questions.explanation: If you are 18 years of age or older, you may choose to become an organ and tissue donor when obtaining your driver license. If you are a male between the ages 18 and 25, the DC DMV will register you with Selective Service unless you use a waiver form to opt out. If you are a citizen of the United States who will be at least 18 years of age by the time of the next election, you may register to vote or update your registration.

questions.question: When passing other vehicles:
questions.answerA: Check your mirrors and blind spots.
questions.answerB: Honk your horn at least three times.
questions.answerC: Re-enter your lane within 10 feet of the passed vehicle.
questions.answerD: There is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: Before passing another vehicle, check your mirrors and blind spots. Before changing lanes, activate the appropriate turn signal. Re-enter the lane when you can see the front of the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: No right turn.
questions.answerC: Slippery when wet.
questions.explanation: Warning signs prepare drivers for upcoming road conditions and hazards and are usually yellow and black. This sign tells drivers that a lane is ending and that they should prepare to allow traffic to merge safely.

questions.question: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for:
questions.answerA: The increased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerB: The decreased stopping distance required by large vehicles.
questions.answerC: The decreased noise of larger vehicles.
questions.answerD: The increased speed of larger vehicles.
questions.explanation: When driving near heavy trucks, other drivers and highway users must make allowances for the increased stopping distance required by the large vehicles. Drivers of smaller vehicles should remain in locations where they can be seen by the driver of the large vehicle and where their view of traffic is not blocked by the vehicle.

questions.question: When driving to an unfamiliar area, you:
questions.answerA: Should depend on road signs to find your way.
questions.answerB: Should plan your trip in advance.
questions.answerC: Only have to know generally where your destination is.
questions.answerD: Should always choose the most direct route.
questions.explanation: When driving to an unfamiliar area, plan your trip in advance. Don’t start with only a hazy idea of where you are going. If your destination is in an unfamiliar area, check the location on a map before you start to drive.

questions.question: When you want to change lanes, you should never:
questions.answerA: Move into another lane while within an intersection.
questions.answerB: Check your blind spot by looking over your shoulder.
questions.answerC: Check for other drivers moving into the same lane.
questions.explanation: You should never change lanes within an intersection. Before changing lanes, always look over your shoulder to check your blind spot. Be alert to other drivers moving into the same lane.

questions.question: Use your headlights on rainy, snowy, or foggy days:
questions.answerB: So others can see your vehicle.
questions.answerC: To warn others of bad weather conditions.
questions.explanation: On rainy, snowy, or foggy days, it may be difficult for other drivers to see your vehicle. Under these conditions, headlights make your vehicle easier to see. If the weather requires you to turn on your windshield wipers, you must also turn on your low beam headlights.

questions.question: Drivers are always required to stop for a stopped school bus when driving on a two-lane road.
questions.answerB: FALSE
questions.explanation: Drivers are always required to stop for a stopped school bus when driving on a two-lane road, regardless of their direction of travel. You should exercise caution when driving near children.

questions.question: What is the only medically proven method of removing alcohol or other drug combinations from your system?
questions.answerB: Give your body time.
questions.answerC: Drink coffee.
questions.explanation: Alcohol takes effect quickly and is slow to leave your system. Cold showers, black coffee, and exercise will do nothing to reduce a person's blood alcohol content (BAC). The only way to lower your BAC is to wait.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Watch for drunk drivers.
questions.answerC: Dangerous curve ahead.
questions.explanation: Warning signs are usually diamond-shaped with black markings on a yellow background. They alert drivers to upcoming hazards. This sign warns drivers to be extra careful when the pavement is wet because the road may become slippery, making vehicles more difficult to control.

questions.question: You may pass another vehicle if the line dividing your lane from the lane you wish to enter is a ____ line.
questions.answerB: Double solid yellow
questions.answerC: Solid yellow
questions.explanation: White lines separate traffic lanes traveling in the same direction. You may cross broken white lines to pass, as long as the passing lane is clear.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Side road.
questions.answerC: Railroad ahead.
questions.explanation: This sign indicates that there is a pedestrian crosswalk.

questions.question: Your brake lights tell other drivers that you:
questions.answerB: Have your emergency brake on.
questions.answerC: Are changing lanes.
questions.explanation: Your vehicle's brake lights indicate to other drivers that you are slowing down or stopping. Your brake lights should always be in working order when you are driving on any roadway.

questions.question: Round signs indicate:
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: Upcoming railroad crossings.
questions.explanation: Round signs warn drivers of an upcoming railroad crossing area. Drivers should use extra caution when approaching a railroad crossing.

questions.question: To enter a gap in highway traffic:
questions.answerA: Watch only the vehicles behind the gap.
questions.answerB: Check behind you, then watch the vehicle ahead.
questions.answerC: Speed up and let the other vehicles make way.
questions.explanation: Whenever you want to change lanes or enter traffic, you must be sure that there are no vehicles in your way in the lane you want to enter. Always check for traffic to the side of and behind your vehicle before you change lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following blocks the smooth flow of traffic?
questions.answerA: Slowing down to look at collision scene.
questions.answerB: Avoiding unnecessary lane changes.
questions.answerC: Using public transportation instead of your vehicle.
questions.explanation: Rubbernecking (the practice of slowing down to look at collisions or other out-of-the-ordinary things) contributes to traffic congestion and should be avoided.

questions.question: When you see other drivers around you acting or reacting in anger:
questions.answerB: Don't react with hand gestures.
questions.answerC: Distance yourself from the situation.
questions.explanation: When other drivers are behaving angrily, you should take action to physically and mentally distance yourself from the situation. Avoid making eye contact with them, or making body movements or gestures that could provoke them. Slow down, move over, or do whatever you safely can to put yourself out of danger.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.answerA: A sudden change in weather calls for a change in driving.
questions.answerB: You should slow down when driving in rain and fog.
questions.answerC: Be particularly aware of vehicles coming up behind you in inclement weather.
questions.explanation: If the weather changes suddenly, you will need to adjust your driving to adapt. Always slow down when driving in rainy or foggy conditions. Be especially aware of vehicles behind you that may be going too fast for conditions.

questions.question: You should allow an extra cushion of space:
questions.answerB: When following a driver who cannot see the rear of their vehicle.
questions.answerC: When following a small passenger car.
questions.explanation: Drivers of trucks, buses, vans, or any vehicles pulling campers or trailers may not be able to see you if you are driving directly behind them. Increase your following distance when driving behind one of these vehicles. Additionally, large vehicles can block your view of the road, so increase your following distance to look around the sides of the vehicle and see the road ahead.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: You must turn right.
questions.answerC: Watch for traffic on your right.
questions.answerD: Don’t park on the right side of the street.
questions.explanation: A sign with a red circle and slash over a symbol indicates that the action represented by the symbol (in this example, a right turn) is not allowed.

questions.question: Work zone barriers, drums, cones, and signs are used to:
questions.answerA: Make drivers angry about slow traffic.
questions.answerB: Inconvenience drivers.
questions.answerC: Keep traffic out of hazardous work zones.
questions.explanation: Work zones on highways have become increasingly dangerous places for both workers and drivers. When approaching a work zone, watch for materials such as cones, barrels, signs, large vehicles, and workers in brightly colored vests to warn you and direct you.

questions.question: It is illegal for a person 21 years of age or older to drive with a minimum blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of:
questions.answerB: 0.08 percent.
questions.answerC: 0.02 percent.
questions.explanation: For drivers age 21 or older, it is illegal to operate a motor vehicle with a blood alcohol concentration (BAC) of 0.08 percent or higher. Driving while under the influence of alcohol is not only illegal, but dangerous.

questions.question: If you miss your exit on the freeway, you should not:
questions.answerA: Continue on the freeway and find an alternate route to your destination.
questions.answerB: Proceed to the next exit, leave the freeway, and return to your proper exit.
questions.answerC: Back up on the road or shoulder.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up in the travel lane or on the shoulder. Continue to drive to the next exit or crossroad. Drivers do not expect a vehicle to be backing toward them on the roadway and doing so will likely cause a collision.

questions.question: If two drivers arrive at the same time to an open intersection:
questions.answerA: The driver on the right has the right-of-way.
questions.answerB: The driver on the left has the right-of-way.
questions.answerC: One driver may continue driving without stopping.
questions.answerD: One driver should honk to indicate that they are giving up the right-of-way.
questions.explanation: If you arrive to an open intersection at the same time as a vehicle to your right, you should yield the right-of-way to that vehicle. You may then proceed when it is safe to do so.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Slow down and use your low beam headlights.
questions.answerB: Slow down and use your high beam headlights.
questions.answerC: Turn your lights on and off to warn other drivers.
questions.explanation: When driving in fog, you should slow down and use your low beam headlights. If the fog is so bad that you cannot see, pull off the road and wait for the fog to clear.

questions.question: You should always travel:
questions.answerA: At the speed of vehicles surrounding you.
questions.answerB: At the speed limit.
questions.answerC: At a speed appropriate for road and weather conditions.
questions.explanation: The speed at which you should drive your vehicle depends on road conditions, the weather, and the legal speed limit. You may never drive above the legal speed limit. Decrease your speed when anything makes conditions less than ideal.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle on a road with two lanes traveling in opposite directions, you should:
questions.answerA: Return to the driving lane when there's enough room between you and the vehicle you passed.
questions.answerB: Remain in the left lane if you intend to turn left.
questions.answerC: Return to the right side of the roadway immediately.
questions.explanation: When passing another vehicle on a two-lane roadway, you must return to the right side of the roadway when there is enough room between you and the vehicle you have passed.

questions.question: This sign means:
questions.answerB: Low shoulder.
questions.answerC: No parking at any time.
questions.explanation: Regulation signs regulate traffic speed and movement, displaying rules which drivers must obey. This regulation sign indicates that drivers should keep right to avoid an upcoming potential driving hazard.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about driving speed is true?
questions.answerA: As your speed increases, the chance of a fatality increases.
questions.answerB: As your speed increases, so should your following distance.
questions.answerC: Both of the above.
questions.explanation: As driving speeds increase, the chance of a fatality in the case of a collision increases. If you are going faster than 80 miles per hour, you have almost no chance of living through a crash. The speed you drive affects your stopping distance, so you should increase your following distance as you increase your speed.

questions.question: On a freeway, you realize you missed your turn or exit. You should:
questions.answerA: Make the turn quickly from your lane of travel.
questions.answerB: Stop and back up.
questions.answerC: Continue driving until you reach the next turn, exit, or other location where you can safely turn around.
questions.answerD: Signal other drivers to stop so you can turn.
questions.explanation: If you miss your turn or exit, do not back up, but go on to the next turn or exit where you can safely turn around. It is illegal to back up on a shoulder or a freeway.

questions.question: When a school bus is stopped ahead on your side of the road with its red lights flashing, you must:
questions.answerA: Slow to a speed no faster than 10 mph.
questions.answerB: Stop until the lights stop flashing.
questions.answerC: Change lanes and pass cautiously.
questions.explanation: The flashing overhead lights and stop arm on a school bus will be activated when the bus is stopped to load or unload students. If approaching a bus using these signals, you may not proceed until the red lights have stopped flashing and the stop arm has been retracted. Never pass a school bus that is dropping off or picking up students.

questions.question: Crossbuck signs indicate:
questions.answerB: School zones.
questions.answerC: No passing zones.
questions.explanation: Crossbuck signs tell drivers to yield to trains at a railroad crossing. Drivers should not try to outdrive a train.

questions.question: This sign indicates a:
questions.answerB: Pedestrian crossing.
questions.answerC: No passing zone.
questions.explanation: Yellow signs with black markings are used to warn drivers about upcoming hazards or special conditions. Round signs are used only to warn about upcoming railroad crossings.

questions.question: When you see this sign, you must:
questions.answerA: Stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic.
questions.answerB: Slow down without coming to a complete stop.
questions.answerC: Stop completely and wait for a green light.
questions.answerD: Slow down and check for traffic.
questions.explanation: Any eight-sided sign is a stop sign. At an intersection with a stop sign, you must stop completely and check for pedestrians and cross traffic in the intersection. Wait for the intersection to clear before proceeding.

questions.question: When you approach an octagonal sign, you must:
questions.answerB: Stop.
questions.answerC: Turn.
questions.explanation: An octagonal (eight-sided) sign always means "Stop." Come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians that have the right-of-way, and proceed when the way is clear.

questions.question: Just like alcohol and other drugs, drowsiness can:
questions.answerA: Help you to be a better driver.
questions.answerB: Make you feel better.
questions.answerC: Impair your judgment.
